Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Single-Crystal, Micro-Source Diffractometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program, Professor Joel Mague from Tulane University and colleagues Robert Pascal, Bruce Gibb and James Donahue will acquire a single crystal X-ray diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector and a micro-source. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) synthesis and structural characterization of complex inorganic molecules; (b) probing limits of synthesis of large, complex inorganic molecules by modular methods; (c) synthesis of sterically hindered thiolate ligands for the stabilization of coordinately unsaturated metal centers of biological significance; (d) assembly and binding properties of deep-cavity cavitands; (e) hydroxycarboxylate complexes of lanthanide metal; and (f) unusual structure and bonding in complex aromatic molecules.

A crystal X-ray diffractometer probes a solid sample with a beam of X-rays to produce a pattern of diffracted rays. This pattern can be deconvoluted to give the chemical structure of the crystalline material. Thus, bond distances and angles between atoms in the crystal can be obtained. This information provides insight into the properties and possible uses of the material. This acquisition will provide faculty and students with modern instrumentation not currently available at the institution and advance their research efforts. It will be used in an undergraduate laboratory course training significant numbers of students. The instrument will used by researchers at Tulane University, Loyola University and Xavier University in New Orleans as well as collaborators at other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The determination of the structures of molecules is important for a variety of reasons. The results can be used to answer questions concerning how atoms are bonded together in the molecule, to aid chemists in figuring out how the molecule in question was formed in the reaction that produced it (particularly if the molecule is not what was predicted to be formed) and to complement studies of potential drug molecules which look at how such molecules can or cannot fit into the active sites of enzymes.

In a growing number of cases in our work, the samples available for study are so small that it has been impossible to obtain sufficient data to permit a satisfactory determination of the structure. This problem has been alleviated to a significant extent with the acquisition of the instrument made possible by this grant. To date, over 400 data sets have been collected of which approximately 75% have produced refined structures. Of the latter, approximately 40% have used samples that required the intense, narrowly focused source of this instrument to obtain usable data. An additional benefit has been the ability to determine the absolute structure (in some cases whether "left-" or "right-handed") of molecules containing only carbon, nitrogen, oxygen and hydrogen.

The structures obtained from this instrument have been of considerable assistance to the research efforts of graduate students in 4 research groups at Tulane and in several departments overseas with which we collaborate. In addition, one undergraduate research project in the Loyola University Chemistry Department has benfited significantly from the presence of this instrument.
